body: I think that means it's finding an older version of the traitlets package somewhere. The version conda lists is the latest, but there must be another version installed somewhere. Try doing `import traitlets; print(traitlets)` in Python to see where it's loading from.

Hi Thomas,

> $ ~/anaconda2/bin/python
> Python 2.7.14 |Anaconda custom (64-bit)| (default, Dec  7 2017, 11:07:58) 
> [GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)] on darwin
> Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
> >>> import traitlets
> >>> print(traitlets)
> <module 'traitlets' from '/Users/mighell/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/traitlets/__init__.pyc'>
> >>> 

I renamed the directory 

/Users/mighell/.local/lib/python2.7

(which dates from 2016) as

/Users/mighell/.local/lib/python2.7_ancient

And now IPython works!

> $ ~/anaconda2/bin/ipython
> Python 2.7.14 |Anaconda custom (64-bit)| (default, Dec  7 2017, 11:07:58) 
> Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
> 
> IPython 5.6.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
> ?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
> %quickref -> Quick reference.
> help      -> Python's own help system.
> object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.
> 
> In [1]: import numpy
> 
> In [2]: print numpy.__version__
> 1.14.0
> 
> In [3]: import traitlets
> 
> In [4]: print(traitlets)
> <module 'traitlets' from '/Users/mighell/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/traitlets/__init__.pyc'>
> 
> In [5]: print traitlets.__version__
> 4.3.2
> 
> In [6]: 


Thank you very very much for your email!


My PATH environment variable has the base Anaconda2 directory (~/anaconda2/bin) 
as the first directory.


The directory

/Users/mighell/.local

is *not* anywhere in my PATH environment variable.


Do you know why IPython looked in the directory 

~/.local

instead of under

~/anaconda2

?


I would consider this IPython behavior to be a user-hostile bug.


Do you possibly know how I can report this bug to the IPython development community?


Thanks again for helping me!

Best regards,

Ken Mighell


P.S.  ~/anaconda2/spyder is now working correctly  :-)


P.P.S.  Just out of curiosity: How in the world did you know/suspect that the errors were 
related to the traitlets package? The phrase traitlets appears nowhere in the traceback 
errors.  




> On Apr 10, 2018, at 11:40 AM, Thomas Kluyver <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> I think that means it's finding an older version of the traitlets package somewhere. The version conda lists is the latest, but there must be another version installed somewhere. Try doing import traitlets; print(traitlets) in Python to see where it's loading from.
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/11084#issuecomment-380205316>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AQw4yUTaEuSuUoPtXKVxAj-jlO7RIO1mks5tnPyVgaJpZM4TNSOb>.
>

Imports aren't affected by PATH - that's for finding commands. It's normal for Python to look in a user-specific location (`~/.local/lib/...` on Linux) first for imports, though it's debatable whether that's appropriate for Anaconda, which is often using a user-writable directory anyway.

If anyone was to change it, it would need to be Anaconda, not IPython - it wouldn't make sense for imports to work differently in IPython from all other Python tools. When they were asked about it a couple of years ago, they didn't seem keen on changing it, though: https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/473

> P.P.S. Just out of curiosity: How in the world did you know/suspect that the errors were related to the traitlets package? The phrase traitlets appears nowhere in the traceback errors.

I don't think there's any easy way unless you're familiar with traitlets. The line the error is coming from creates a `Unicode()` instance (capital U, not the native Python 2 `unicode` type), and then calls the `.tag()` method on it. When you see a lot of traitlets code, both of those things are clear signs of traitlets being involved. And I know that the `.tag()` method was added in a version some time ago, so if the error is that it's missing, that tells me it's probably an older version of traitlets. :-)
Closing because, while this is certainly confusing, it's not a bug in IPython. Feel free to keep using the comments to discuss it.

Hi Thomas,

> On Apr 10, 2018, at 1:15 PM, Thomas Kluyver <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> Imports aren't affected by PATH - that's for finding commands. It's normal for Python to look in a user-specific location (~/.local/lib/... on Linux) first for imports, though it's debatable whether that's appropriate for Anaconda, which is often using a user-writable directory anyway.
> 
> If anyone was to change it, it would need to be Anaconda, not IPython - it wouldn't make sense for imports to work differently in IPython from all other Python tools. When they were asked about it a couple of years ago, they didn't seem keen on changing it, though: ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues#473 <https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/473>
> 

Why not have a simple assertion within IPython to test that the version number of the imported 
traitlets package be be sufficiently high enough to support the .tag() method?

Alternatively, from ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues#473 <https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/473> discussion, it appears that the assertion 
test might be put in the Anaconda Python packageâ€™s site.py file. 
> P.P.S. Just out of curiosity: How in the world did you know/suspect that the errors were related to the traitlets package? The phrase traitlets appears nowhere in the traceback errors.
> 
> I don't think there's any easy way unless you're familiar with traitlets. The line the error is coming from creates a Unicode() instance (capital U, not the native Python 2 unicode type), and then calls the .tag() method on it. When you see a lot of traitlets code, both of those things are clear signs of traitlets being involved. And I know that the .tag() method was added in a version some time ago, so if the error is that it's missing, that tells me it's probably an older version of traitlets. :-)
> 

So high-level guru experience!  

Thanks again for your help!

-Ken


> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/11084#issuecomment-380232028>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AQw4yR8dwLS5l8_Crj2MxMagwiMxpqaZks5tnRLJgaJpZM4TNSOb>.
>

> Why not have a simple assertion within IPython to test that the version number of the imported traitlets package be be sufficiently high enough to support the .tag() method?

IPython has a dependency on traitlets, which is the standard way of specifying this kind of thing. It's up to packaging tools like conda or pip how to ensure that the necessary dependencies are available. I don't want to start duplicating our dependencies as assertions in the code. We'll just forget to update them.

Hi Thomas,

> On Apr 11, 2018, at 3:06 AM, Thomas Kluyver <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> Why not have a simple assertion within IPython to test that the version number of the imported traitlets package be be sufficiently high enough to support the .tag() method?

> IPython has a dependency on traitlets, which is the standard way of specifying this kind of thing. It's up to packaging tools like conda or pip how to ensure that the necessary dependencies are available. I don't want to start duplicating our dependencies as assertions in the code. We'll just forget to update them.
> 

I have communicated with some of the Anaconda team and they say this is an IPython issue.

Sigh... 


Cheers,

-Ken



> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/11084#issuecomment-380399216>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AQw4yTA7BkOY5ktnWrITKdq9fRXctdfLks5tndW6gaJpZM4TNSOb>.

Sorry to hear that. It's not really anyone's issue per se - every piece is working as designed, it's just that the net effect is not what you're expecting. It's definitely not an IPython issue, though: you happen to have encountered the problem with IPython and traitlets, but the same underlying confusion about imports could affect any Python package at all.

The only plausible 'fix' I see for this general issue is for Anaconda to disable `ENABLE_USER_SITE`. I often modify Anaconda on my own computer to do this. But since they didn't do it straight away, changing it now would undoubtedly bring complaints from a different group of people who make use of the feature the way it is.

Feel free to point the Anaconda team to this issue if they want to understand the problem more.

>

But since they didn't do it straight away, changing it now would undoubtedly bring complaints from a different group of people who make use of the feature the way it is.
> 
That is a very good idea.  It would make Anaconda more robust while still allowing ~/.local to be
used by power users.

-Ken
